Page Name: ACRES Frequently Asked Questions | US EPA
Brief Description: Modification to content on the ACRES FAQ page. Note: ACRES stands fopr Assessment, Cleanup, and Redevelopment Exchange System and is an online database that recipients of Brownfield grants use to submit data to the EPA. Three categories of FAQ information have been removed (General Information, General Property Information, and Property-Specific Information). The prior FAQ's were extensive (21 questions and answers) and quite specific (as in, questions could plausibly have been submitted by members of the public); the new page  is substantially reduced-- they are generic FAQs (all new) and there are only 4 of them. Additionally an email address was removed (acres_help@epa.gov) along with a link to a report entitled "Institutional Controls: A Guide to Planning, Implementing, Maintaining, and Enforcing Institutional Controls at Contaminated Sites (pdf)"

Page Name: Funding Opportunities about Wasted Food | US EPA
Brief Description: The EPA webpage "Funding Opportunities about Wasted Food" was removed in its entirety and now responds with a "Sorry, but this web page does not exist," 404 error. Justice communities, and other federal agency grants from the US Department of agriculture related to sustainable food systems. This seems very significant and the grant information mentions dollar amounts that are in the hundreds of millions of dollars. Many outgoing links also removed. Multiple grant deadlines are mentioned as upcoming in March and May 2025. Deletion of that info suggests that these grant programs and application cycles are being terminated or substantially altered.

EPA is developing three new waste prevention, reuse, and recycling programs". New language is in the past tense and deleted health/equity/resilience langage. Now reads: "The Bipartisan Infrastructure Law is a historic investment in American communities. EPA developed three new waste prevention, reuse, and recycling programs."
